results.title: Anzac: a nation's heritage
results.brief_description: The ANZAC performance at Gallipoli is examined as are the towns that are there today and the graves that remain. Likens the ANZACS to the Greek heroes of ancient times. This is an edited version of a commemorative film made in 1965, 50 years after the landing of Australian and New Zealand troops at Gallipoli on April 25th, 1915. Highlights include memorial services in Australia, New Zealand and Britain, a re-enactment at Anzac Cove and scenes of Gallipoli and Troy today.

results.title: Anzac Day: World War 1 (Yrs 9-11)
results.brief_description: Presented by Richard Morecroft, this program looks at empire building alliances and events which led to the start of World War I. It presents the romance of war, life and death at Gallipoli and Australian campaigns in the Sinai desert and in Europe.

results.title: Anzac Day: World War 1
results.brief_description: Richard Morecroft presents an overview of Australian involvementt in World War I, concentrating primarily on the Gallipoli campaign. Provides background history ot the war, the reasons for Australia’s involvement, and details the events at Gallipoli whilst mentioning the arenas of combat in which Australian soldiers fought. Uses stills, archival footage, footage from propaganda and feature films related to World War I. Useful background to the story of Anzac Day, mentioning Simpson and his donkey, Turkish bravery and perceptions of the war. (SCHOOL PROGRAM ON THE GREAT WAR-SUITABLE FOR PRIMARY SCHOOL CHILDREN)

results.title: Anywhere Out of the World
results.brief_description: ‘Anywhere Out of the World’ (2000) is part of No Ghost Just a Shell (1999-2003), a project born in collaboration with the artist Pierre Huyghe that explores the relationship between forms of producing, distributing and perceiving artworks.

constellations_other.name: Analogue and digital film
constellations_other.description: Though technology has evolved since celluloid film strips were invented, contemporary filmmakers and artists still appreciate and celebrate the analogue in a digital world.

results.description: Anywhere Out of the World (2000) is part of No Ghost Just a Shell (1999-2003), a project born in collaboration with the artist Pierre Huyghe that explores the relationship between forms of producing, distributing and perceiving artworks. In 1999 Parreno and Huyghe bought the rights to a Japanese manga character they named “Annlee”. They lifted all copyrights from the character, asking other artists and designers to create various artworks with Annlee as a protagonist. Parreno’s film is the first episode in this series of projects, and is characterized by a unique sequence in which Annlee presents herself as a girl without a past, and declares her existence as a product free of any copyright or market restrictions. Annlee’s voice was created digitally by the artist. Her presence has an ambiguous quality: she is a melancholy character, devoid of quality, deigned to remain a simulated reality. In addition to dealing with themes of copyright and authorship, the artwork reflects on the ways and circumstances that lead to the definition of an identity in the contemporary era.
description_for_label: Anywhere Out of the World (2000) is part of No Ghost Just a Shell (1999-2003), a project born in collaboration with the artist Pierre Huyghe that explores the relationship between forms of producing, distributing and perceiving artworks. In 1999 Parreno and Huyghe bought the rights to a Japanese manga character they named “Annlee”. They lifted all copyrights from the character, asking other artists and designers to create various artworks with Annlee as a protagonist. Parreno’s film is the first episode in this series of projects, and is characterized by a unique sequence in which Annlee presents herself as a girl without a past, and declares her existence as a product free of any copyright or market restrictions. Annlee’s voice was created digitally by the artist. Her presence has an ambiguous quality: she is a melancholy character, devoid of quality, deigned to remain a simulated reality. In addition to dealing with themes of copyright and authorship, the artwork reflects on the ways and circumstances that lead to the definition of an identity in the contemporary era.

results.title: Anyway...what is an Australian?
results.creator_credit: Barbara Boyd and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: Views the concept of multiculturalism through the eyes of several Australians in multicultural Melbourne. Through these people’s lives, the most typical element of Australian society is seen to be a continuing pattern of cultural interchange. A spectrum of ideas, attitudes and values which reflect the diversity of opinions, traditions and life-styles current among the Australian population. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Anybody's problem
results.creator_credit: John Fletcher, Leon Clore and Basic Films
results.brief_description: In Britain, the Citizens’ Advice Bureaux give free and expert counsel on problems as different as an eviction threat, the making of a will, a broken marriage and a scooter accident. Shot in Stevenage New Town, the film also illustrates the pattern of life in this new community, one of several designed to ease the population pressure on London.

results.title: Any questions?
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission, Victorian Film Corporation and Seven Dimensions
results.brief_description: Discussion starter looking at the problems of generating group discussions. After completing a complicated explanation, a trainer asks questions of the group. In his despair at failing to elicit questions he jumps out the window.

results.title: Any friends or relations
results.brief_description: A tractor safety film which investigates the many kinds of accidents which can happen. Shows how the operator’s personal failures can cause accidents. Gives valuable safety hints on the operation of tractors. Suitable for rural and construction
